body: Murders in New York City have dropped, again. So low has the number dipped -- to 566 so far this year from a high of 2,245 in 1990 -- that even Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has begun to gently lower the public's expectations, warning of a core number of homicides resistant to even New York's gargantuan police force. Low crime rates are more
title: As Murders Fall, New Tactics Are Tried Against Remainder

body: A Queens man was shot to death yesterday afternoon by two teenagers who were waiting for him when he walked purposefully through a shopping mall and into an obscure basement bathroom, the police said. The victim, Walter Rodriguez, 31, of 88th Avenue in Jamaica, stumbled from the men's room in the basement of Jamaica Colosseum Mall and staggered
title: Man Is Killed by 2 Youths in Queens Mall, Police Say

body: AT 3 a.m. one humid night over the summer, two bored teenagers chased a homeless man named Billy Pearson through the streets of East New York, Brooklyn. They cornered him in a yard next to St. Gabriel Roman Catholic Church on New Lots Avenue, near the soup kitchen where he ate breakfast most mornings. There, the police say, they beat him to death
title: The House That Sal Built

body: A carpenter who works long hours then comes home to the rough-hewn East New York neighborhood of Brooklyn, Morris Rogers wants nothing more than to read for fun with his 13-year-old daughter, Amony, and help her with her homework. But there are after-work realities, cumbersome chores like lugging bags of clothes to wash at the self-service laundry.
title: Reading, Writing and the Rinse Cycle

body: Workers at a private bus company that serves 8,000 riders a day in southern and eastern Brooklyn staged a sickout yesterday to protest their lack of a contract, complicating commuting just days before the Christmas holiday and catching city officials off guard. The job action, by 200 drivers, mechanics and other workers at the Command Bus Company
title: Bus Workers Stage Sickout To Protest Lack of Contract

body: Nola Dossantos spends her nights in a windowless room at the back of an elegant restaurant. She deals in solicitous smiles and dollops of liquid soap, then turns on the tap, waiting obligingly with a sheet of paper towel. She is stoic with the haughty and generous to the confessional. On a bad night, when a woman has had a few too many cosmos, she
title: Standing Sentry, Armed With Towel; Some Valets Earn Little; Others Have No Complaints

body: NOW comes the petitioner, Sharon Richardson, formerly of Brooklyn and lately of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, to ask that George E. Pataki, governor of the State of New York, grant her clemency. Mercy, she asks. Just as state government has an application procedure for a driver's license or a liquor license, so too does it have one for
title: About New York; Making Her Case For Mercy

body: A police officer, who was seriously injured nearly two months ago when he fell off a slick rooftop while searching for a burglar in Brooklyn, died early yesterday after having a seizure at his home, the police said. The officer, William Rivera, 35, became the fourth New York City officer to die in the line of duty this year. He had served for 12
title: Officer Who Fell From Roof In October Dies After Seizure

body: THE director of fitness and physical education for the New York City public schools stands to greet a reporter in a conference room at the Tweed Courthouse downtown. The director, Lori Benson, wears a softly cut black business suit, funky black leather square-toed shoes, a heavy silver necklace and matching bracelet, artfully applied makeup, four
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Crunching Fitness Into Phys Ed at School

body: A 4-year-old Brooklyn boy was critically injured yesterday when he fell out a second-floor window and landed headfirst on a concrete drive, Fire Department officials and neighbors said. The boy, Muhamad Aboalsaud, was standing at a window at 1502 West Fifth Street, at Avenue O, in Bensonhurst, about 1:20 p.m. when the screen gave way and he fell
title: Brooklyn Boy, 4, Is Severely Injured in 2nd-Floor Fall

body: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that, after a preliminary investigation, the fatal shooting of a homeless man by an officer in Brooklyn on Monday appeared to be justified. Mr. Kelly, left, also said that the inquiry into the shooting death of the man, Jose Feliciano, 44, had just begun and that the matter would be presented to a
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Commissioner Calls Shooting Justified

body: A Brooklyn man who frequently had seizures that sent him running into traffic was shot and killed by police officers early yesterday morning when he swung at them with a light fixture, the authorities said. The police did not immediately identify the man yesterday. But neighbors who gathered at Sutter and Sheffield Avenues in East New York
title: Man Swinging Light Fixture Killed by Police in Brooklyn

body: A man walked into the 75th Precinct station house early yesterday morning and told officers that he had killed a woman at his apartment, according to the police. When officers went to the apartment, at 260 Montauk Avenue in East New York, they discovered the body of a 40-year-old woman who had been stabbed to death, the police said. She was
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Admits Slaying, Police Say

body: He is the man who wipes off your table at McDonald's, the one you hardly notice in the swirl of trays and people. Antonio Gonzales, 23, keeps out of the way of customers as he swiftly mops the floor and empties the garbage cans at a McDonald's in Queens. He is shy, with a gentle handshake and tattooed arms bearing the names of loved ones. These are
title: The Neediest Cases; His First Difficult Steps To Reading and a Paycheck

body: Growing up in East New York, Brooklyn, Russell Jones, who became famous as the rapper Ol' Dirty Bastard, spent his summers working whatever odd jobs he could line up. But it was in one particular job, selling newspapers at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, that he displayed some of the traits that would propel him in his career. While his fellow
title: Recalling a Man of Many Names, One of Them Dirty; The Life and Death of a Hip-Hop Jester: Joy, Fame and Endless Struggle

body: ''The Island Lady has taken a vacation from it all,'' Tiffani Ross Parker said, pointing to her painting of a woman reclining seaside under a coconut tree and a hot pink sky. ''She's just chillin' all by herself.'' Ms. Parker, who says she suffers from bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, never liked being by herself. When her mother suddenly died
title: The Neediest Cases; When Art Helps to Deal With Harsh Realities

body: FOR a New Yorker just one day shy of turning 100 years old, the subway kept crazy hours yesterday. In other words, there were no hours it did not keep. As its neighbors around the world locked up their stations and turned out their lights, the subway started a new day, just as it has more than 36,000 times since Oct. 27, 1904. A few minutes after
title: A Day in the Subway, as It Rolls Up a Century

body: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Oct. 6 about the arrest of a Brooklyn student on charges of gun possession included an outdated name from an Education Department official for the school where the pistol was found. It is the East Brooklyn Congregations-East New York High School for Public Safety and Law, no longer the High School for Public
title: Corrections

body: Specialist Zac Bullock leaned against a dust-caked wall in the shade of the abandoned Iraqi school that had become his temporary home, talking politics. ''Some of the guys don't talk about the election much,'' said Specialist Bullock, 20, a medic from Redding, Calif., who had just treated a gash two inches deep in an infantryman's foot. ''But most
title: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE MILITARY; From Troops More Attuned to Bullets Than Ballots, a Few Votes for a Quick Way Home

body: While many parts of Brooklyn have been experiencing well-publicized revivals, this is not the case in the worn commercial area at the intersection of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in the Midwood section. Now, however, a Queens developer is preparing to construct a three-story retail complex anchored by a Target store on the site, formerly owned by
title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Brooklyn; 3-Story Shopping Complex For Area Short on Retailing

body: After a week of tearing through concrete and sifting through dirt, F.B.I. agents and police detectives unearthed several parts of a human skeleton yesterday, along with a wristwatch and pair of glasses, in what they believe is an old mob graveyard in a marshy vacant lot in Queens, officials and investigators said. The authorities believe that as
title: F.B.I. Finds Human Bones At a Mob Dig

body: A Brooklyn man was arrested after his 3-year-old son shot his 6-year-old daughter yesterday afternoon with a pellet gun the boy found in the family's home on Loring Avenue in East New York, the police said. The man, Jason Castro, 27, was charged with endangering the welfare of a child and with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Mr.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Father Charged After Son, 3, Shoots Sister

body: FOR the fourth year in a row, the number of New York City students meeting math standards rose, according to data that the state's Department of Education released last week. Once again, the city's gains, based on the results of tests given in the spring to all fourth and eighth graders, outpaced the state's. In New York City, 68.1 percent of
title: How Fourth Graders Fared on the State Math Test

body: DINA CALHOUN will soon switch roles from renter to landlord -- a transformation she holds as sort of a mission. Ms. Calhoun, an administrative clerk for Verizon Communications, has run the rental gantlet -- six apartments in 24 years. Eventually, a generous landlady in Brooklyn helped make it possible for Ms. Calhoun, a single mother of three, to
title: FOR RENT; The Journey From Renter to Landlord

body: Usmanu Salisu surveyed the tabletop scene: potatoes, apples, watermelons and squash. ''This is good, real good, and it's all fresh,'' Mr. Salisu said, inspecting a ripe Cortland apple. ''I don't see it this good at the supermarket.'' That's just what Ena Nemley wants to hear. Every week, Ms. Nemley rounds up green beans and collard greens from the
title: Bleak Landscapes, Green Produce; Poor Neighborhoods See Rise in Farmers' Markets

body: A student at the High School for Public Service in East New York was arrested yesterday on charges of gun possession after the police found an unloaded 9-millimeter pistol in his locker, a police spokesman said yesterday. The school's mission is to prepare students for careers in public safety and law. The student, Anthony Jones, 17, will be
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Gun In School Locker Leads To Arrest

body: The expression ''sleeping with the fishes,'' while evocative, is somewhat misleading. In reality, organized crime figures more often than not entomb their victims in concrete floors, swamps or garbage dumps or leave them in the trunks of cars. And the corpse left bleeding in the street, an indelible mob message that long ago sowed fear in certain
title: Sometimes, Mob Victims Have Plenty of Company

body: John Favara, a Queens man who managed a Long Island furniture company, had the misfortune of running over John Gotti's 12-year-old son nearly a quarter of a century ago, a fatal accident that was followed four months later by Mr. Favara's disappearance. Philip Giaccone and Dominic Trinchera were up-and-coming figures in the Bonanno crime family
title: F.B.I. Is Searching With Backhoes In a Reputed Mob Dumping Ground

body: It has become a familiar New York story: Another neighborhood written off as doomed becomes the Next New Thing. Twenty-five years ago, dowdy TriBeCa, the Upper West Side and Park Slope began blossoming into some of the city's most alluring places to live, prompting thousands of daydreaming home buyers to slap their heads and ask, ''Why didn't I buy
title: The Next TriBeCa? Stick a Pin in the Map

body: IF conditions for cyclists have improved in recent years, it has not hurt that several prominent New Yorkers have taken it up. Ruth W. Messinger, the former mayoral candidate, made completing the Manhattan waterfront greenway a crusade. Mayor Bloomberg's deputy mayor for economic development, Daniel L. Doctoroff, rides his bike to work, and Parks
title: Senator Pothole He's Not

body: LIKE many children of Holocaust survivors, Eleanor Reissa grew up wanting to move away from her parents' Yiddish-fraught world, to paddle in the American mainstream. ''I stand on the shoulders of my family,'' she will say, then quickly add, with a spritz of wit that animates her conversation: ''At least with one foot. The other foot is actively
title: PUBLIC LIVES; From Yiddish Chestnuts, Fresh Song

body: An article on Sept. 22 about Joan E. Mahon-Powell, a former New York City schools official who admitted that she had used false credentials to rise through the ranks, misidentified the location of Junior High School 292, where she was promoted to principal in 1997. It is in the East New York section of Brooklyn, not Bushwick. The article also
title: Corrections

body: ON a visit to Israel, the Rev. Dr. Johnny Ray Youngblood stopped at the Western Wall and was moved by the weeping and praying of thousands of Jews who went there to mourn their great catastrophe, the destruction of the second temple in Jerusalem by the Romans. ''It is like organized grief work,'' Dr. Youngblood said, describing the mourning he saw
title: An Old Journey Forged in Pain; A Remembrance Born to Heal

body: HER name is Maria Piedad Cano, but friends call her Piedad. ''There are so many Marias where I'm from,'' she said, chuckling, as she slathered margarine over Colombian corncakes sizzling on a propane-powered griddle. It was 10:45 p.m., and the Friday night bar crowd on Roosevelt Avenue hovered hungrily around her sidewalk kitchen. An hour earlier
title: Street Corner Cooks Have Names, Too

body: From humble beginnings as a substitute teacher in the late 1970's, Joan E. Mahon-Powell climbed through the ranks of the New York City school system, becoming a principal, a superintendent in Brooklyn, the superintendent of a citywide district for low-performing schools and then chief of staff to Chancellor Harold O. Levy. Last year, Mr. Levy's
title: Former City Schools Official Admits Using False Credentials

body: In late July, Oliver Griffin, 58, was staying at the Charles H. Gay shelter for homeless men in New York City while recovering from spinal surgery when, he said, a new caseworker brought him what sounded like good news. He was being transferred to another shelter, where he would be allowed to rest in his bed during the day. Mr. Griffin knew nothing
title: Homeless Men Were Shunted Into a Notorious Adult Home

body: A woman in East New York, Brooklyn, found her son's girlfriend brutally beaten and stabbed yesterday morning, shortly after learning that her son had been in a bad car crash. Now the son, Teon Brummell, 27, is the main suspect in the killing, an investigator said, but he was hospitalized last night and had not been charged with any crime. At 9:30
title: Brooklyn Woman Found Slain After Boyfriend Crashes Car

body: Gathering under a swampy gray sky in Brooklyn, thousands of mourners said their farewells yesterday to Detective Robert L. Parker, ending an agonizing week of wakes and eulogies for the detective and his partner, who was slain along with him. The two men were killed on Sept. 10 as they confronted a domestic violence suspect, and the services for
title: For a Slain Detective, The Show Was the Thing

body: WHEN Irwin and I got married, it was a casual affair in my parents' backyard. My mother made a tenderloin and a turkey salad, and my sister made bread. Uncle George brought his homegrown tomatoes, and my father poured Champagne into plastic glasses. The next day we found the turkey salad. It was on top of the refrigerator. Since then Irwin has
title: CLOSE TO HOME; Hell on Wheels: The Home-Wrecker in the Backyard

body: ''Hi -- what school are you here for?'' Les Ford, the sweet-voiced man standing by the front door, asked as students arrived yesterday morning for the opening of classes. It was a question that in other years might have seemed odd, even flat-out crazy, given the large sign above the front door proclaiming the building at 400 Pennsylvania Avenue to
title: A Calm, but Confusing, First Day of School

body: A 33-year-old man was charged yesterday in the robbery of a Roman Catholic nun near her convent in July, the police said. Detectives identified the man, Miguel Hacha, through descriptions and found him in a homeless shelter, officials said, and the nun identified him in a lineup. The police say Mr. Hacha grabbed the nun, Sister Ngozi Ohari, near
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Robbery Of Nun

title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: A suspect was shot in the knee and a pit bull was killed yesterday after the police chased four robbery suspects into a house in East New York and an officer fired several shots when he was charged by the dog, the authorities said. The man who was injured was in the line of fire and was shot accidentally, the police said. He was in stable condition
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Shoot Robbery Suspect

body: In the Bronx, paint-splattered Pepe Jeans and Air Jordan sneakers were all the rage. In Brooklyn, it was all about preppy long-sleeved button-down shirts set off with earrings shaped like Jesus' face. And in Manhattan, tiny hands reached for Lacoste shirts in every color of the rainbow, and anything, but anything, made by Juicy Couture. So began
title: Fashion? A Subject They Already Know

body: A man was fatally shot early yesterday during a gunfight with the police after he tried to rob a 24-hour carwash in Brooklyn, the police and witnesses said. The suspect exchanged gunfire with three officers about 1:50 a.m. outside DT's Car Wash, at Linden Boulevard and Fountain Avenue in East New York. No police officers, car wash employees or
title: Carwash Robbery Suspect Is Killed by Police

body: CONVENTIONEERS, already booked into dozens of events, have been inundated with official advice about what to visit in New York. Corey Kilgannon of The New York Times asked some prominent New Yorkers where they would take delegates to see the real New York. PHILIP LOPATE, the writer: ''I'd take them to areas of the Manhattan waterfront, like many
title: NEW YORK 2004: NAVIGATING NEW YORK/WHAT TO SEE; City to Republicans: See This. Telling the Delegates Where to Go

body: Sixty-nine people, most of them members of five closely linked families, have been indicted on conspiracy charges that accuse them of cooperating as one enormous narcotics trafficker to peddle heroin and cocaine in Brooklyn housing projects, prosecutors announced yesterday. The oldest suspect is a 61-year-old woman, while the youngest, from another
title: 69 Indicted In Drug Ring At Projects In Brooklyn

body: IN the last week of July, on a steamy evening, Sandra Bernhard was holding forth in downtown Brooklyn at the new Target, entertaining the hundreds of guests who had come to celebrate the store's opening. It was a significant moment for a number of reasons. The Target is part of the Atlantic Terminal, a new mall built by Forest City Ratner. It is
title: SQUARE FEET/Downtown Brooklyn; At Site Dodgers Rejected, Target Store Is a Hit

body: A man was fatally shot near his home late Wednesday as he climbed out of his car, the authorities said yesterday. The police said it was unclear whether the man, Kutub Siblee, 21, knew his assailant. The shooting took place about 10:15 p.m. in front of 556 Drew Street, just a few doors away from the building where he lived, in East New York. He was
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed Near His Home

body: SO you doubled your money on your condo and you think it's time to start your own real estate dynasty. Or perhaps you just want to build something both beautiful and substantial, a graceful blend of brick, steel and glass, that will make you both proud and rich. If you hear the inner voice of the master builder inside you, you are not alone. At
title: In a Hot Market, Everyone Wants To Be a Developer

body: When Curtis Sliwa, the self-appointed subway crime fighter and combative talk show host, was shot in the back of a New York City cab 12 years ago, it did not take long for cynical speculation to begin. Perhaps, some theorized, Mr. Sliwa had arranged to be shot in an unorthodox bid for publicity. For years, however, Mr. Sliwa stuck to his own theory
title: Godfather to Son: Gottis Set Up a Hit On Sliwa, U.S. Says

body: On the night of Sept. 11, 2001, Police Officer Joseph Rodriguez was in as bad shape as many who lived through that day. A witness clearly remembers seeing him staring blankly in a hospital emergency room. His knee was broken, and he was still except for his hands, which worked at shredding chunks of gauze. Officer Rodriguez, now 27, never seemed to
title: For Officer in Pipe Bomb Inquiry, 9/11 Scars Never Healed

body: A man who was shot by a police officer on Saturday while he was trying to break into a car was charged yesterday with assault, menacing and attempted grand larceny, the police said. The man, identified by the police as Kevin Bonds, 36, of 1305 Loring Avenue in East New York, who was arrested after the shooting on Saturday, had been listed in stable
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot By Police Is Charged

body: Four million cubic yards of silt from the bottom of New York Harbor would be needed to raise the height of the property so that it would not be underwater during severe rainstorms. title: Companies Face Major Obstacles in Plan to Bring Nascar to S.I.

body: A Roman Catholic nun wearing her habit was attacked and robbed yesterday on a street corner a block and a half from her convent in Brooklyn, the police said. The nun, Sister Ngozi Ohari, 41, was walking on Shepherd Avenue near the corner of Glenmore Avenue about 5:15 a.m. when she was grabbed from behind and thrown to the ground, the police said.
title: Brooklyn Nun Is Recovering After Attack Near Convent

body: A police officer was shot in the hand last night after trying to stop a car in East New York, the police said. The officer, in a patrol car, tried to pull over a Ford Expedition that had driven through a stop sign at Alabama Avenue and Blake Avenue about 8:30 p.m., the police said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Shot In Hand

body: On many mornings this year, the sun had yet to come up when Leeann Romero, Heidi Alvia's 12-year-old daughter, boarded a yellow bus outside her home in East New York, bound for school on the other side of Brooklyn. And on many days, the bus would not get to Intermediate School 228 until well into the second or third period. This meant that Leeann,
title: Alvia-Delgado Family; Treated 'Like Yo-Yos'

body: For Soledad Franco of the Bronx and her two teenagers, the 2003-4 school year brought stunning highs -- a principal personally called to say that her daughter had been accepted to one of the city's new small high schools -- and hair-pulling lows, like the day she opened a letter and discovered that the school would move next year. For the Romanos,
title: As Their School System Changes, Frenzied Families Try to Adapt

body: Two and a half years after an American Airlines plane crashed in the Rockaways en route to the Dominican Republic, two-thirds of the families of the 265 people who died have accepted settlement offers stemming from the accident. The settlements will require many of these mostly Dominican families -- some of whom did not even have bank accounts --
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; In Tragedy's Wake, Money That Soothes Can Also Complicate

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CANARSIE; For Some in a Proud Neighborhood, a Free Gift Bears Too High a Price

Two 15-year-old Brooklyn boys were arrested last night and charged with second-degree murder in the attack, the police said. They were
title: Homeless Man Dies in Beating; Police Arrest 2 Teenagers

Riccobono, left, was fired by Rudy Crew, then the chancellor, in June 1999, in a purge of superintendents in low-performing districts. After the test scores
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: School District Superintendent Vindicated

Hart speeding off in an instant: there was a fire burning out of control on the 20th floor of an East Side apartment building. The first fire engines and ladders had already arrived at the scene. But it was Chief Hart who was now rolling toward the
title: A New Weapon for Firefighters; Fire Dept. Gets Better Radio, but Needs Much More

Over four years, prosecutors and police said, a group of drug crews turned the Ingersoll
title: Dozens Indicted in Crackdown on a Brooklyn Drug Ring

title: ON EDUCATION; Increasingly, African-Americans Take Flight to Private Schools

title: Steady Focus, Evolving Vision

body: By noon throughout the city, the faithful find their way to faded green storefronts. title: Win or Lose, a Place to Show; For Regulars, Betting Sites Double as Social Clubs

body: WALKING through her backyard filled with stately trees and masses of tulips on a recent Saturday, Esther Bronstein looked up in the sky to see a summer visitor, a falcon, soaring overhead. ''It's back,'' she said of the bird, describing it as a reminder that summer and another important return, that of 9-year-old Tyree Lewis, is not far away.
title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Second Year of Games In the Scarsdale Sun

title: Suburban Retailing for the New Brooklyn

body: Anyone who has wondered why mayors rarely tackle public education as a signature issue might consider the predicament of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. He fought for and won control of the city school system, sold off the old Board of Education headquarters at 110 Livingston Street, revamped the administrative bureaucracy and moved it to the Tweed
title: On Mayor's Favorite Issue, Poll Offers No Pat on Back

body: Tony Avella, a city councilman from the northern shores of Queens, speaks passionately about running for mayor next year. Having won his seat in a competitive race in 2001, he acknowledges that he is a long shot in the 2005 Democratic primary, since he is barely known outside his district. ''My chances of winning are slim to none,'' Mr. Avella said
title: For Some Politicians, a Losing Race Isn't Always a Total Loss

body: A 64-year-old woman died in a fire in her Brooklyn home yesterday afternoon, the police said. The woman, Bernice Burney, was found dead inside her apartment, which was on the second floor of a two-story house at 675 Essex Street in East New York, the police said. They added that there were no signs of foul play. The fire was reported at about 5
title: Woman Is Killed in a Fire

body: Someone must have seen something. Two days after her 2 1/2-year-old son, sitting in his father's lap, was killed in a hail of bullets directly across the street from a Brooklyn apartment complex, Alicia Barriere begged yesterday for witnesses to come forward. ''I just want anybody who knows anything to please, say something,'' Ms. Barriere, 26,
title: Mother Seeks Witnesses to the Murder of Boy, 2

body: Once a month, in a windowless courtroom at 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan, children are summoned before a judge who can decide whether they will be removed from the United States. One afternoon, there is a Haitian girl of 17 who escaped her father's killers; another time, a 15-year-old Ecuadoran who came 3,000 miles to earn money for his ailing
title: Children Alone and Scared, Fighting Deportation

author: Randy Kennedy, a reporter for The Times, is the author of ''Subwayland,'' a collection of his Tunnel Vision columns, published last month by St. Martin's Griffin.
body: OVER the next several months, as the centennial of the subway's opening approaches, New Yorkers will hear a lot about the most momentous dates in the long and fascinating life of their mass transit system. Commemorating these events -- the first train from City Hall to Harlem; the deadly Malbone Street wreck; the unification of the subway system
title: 1904-2004; True but Strange

body: A 69-year-old man tried to kill three law enforcement officers by dropping a 16-pound bowling ball at them from the terrace of his 17th-floor apartment, police officials said yesterday. The ball narrowly missed the officers, and the district attorney in Brooklyn charged the man, Douglas Stiff of East New York, with attempted murder, attempted
title: Bowling Ball From 17th Floor Almost Hits 3 Brooklyn Officers

body: DEAR DIARY: Recently I wanted to get rid of some old foreign currency I had from a trip to Europe, pre-euro. I went to my bank and gave the teller bills from the Netherlands. She looked at them for a while and then asked, ''What is this?'' I said it was Dutch money. ''From Denmark?'' she replied. ''No,'' I said, ''Holland.'' She proceeded to scroll
title: Metropolitan Diary

author: E-mail: amh@nytimes.com
body: ON the day of the audition, Ray Aramis Rae woke up early as usual in his apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He meditated -- he could never start the day without meditating -- cooked himself a bowl of oatmeal and shaved his head. The casting notice had been clear: ''NEEDED: 8 African-American men with stage experience, 20's-40's, 5'10'' or taller,
title: COPING; Will Shave Head, and Dream Dreams

body: New York City's subways are cleaner than they were a year ago, according to a rider advocacy group's sixth annual survey of the system. This year, 66 percent of cars were rated as ''clean,'' up from 59 percent last year and 47 percent the year before, the Straphangers Campaign's report showed. Since 1999, the percentage of clean cars has more than
title: More Subway Cars Are Clean, A Group's Survey Reports

body: Stephen Todd Booker, who at 50 has been on death row for more than half his life, was explaining how his imagination kept working without the stimuli that most people take for granted. ''I remember thinking one time -- I'd already been here a while -- and I realized I hadn't seen a star in 12 years,'' he said in an interview at the Union
title: A Poet's Spirit Springs to Life On Death Row; Following a Brutal Crime, A Literary Reputation Grows

body: The meals come one a day, Monday through Friday, with an extra frozen meal for the weekend. One day it is a pork chop with broccoli and mashed potatoes. The next it is meatballs and macaroni. Then lemon chicken with baked potato and spinach. To Marge Marcone, who lives in the Fordham section of the Bronx, the doorbell signaling the arrival of her
title: For Lunch, a Party of One; By Switching to Frozen Meals, Program May Further Isolate Some Elderly

body: An article in some copies on Sunday about the investigation into the shooting and robbery on Jan. 17 at the Galaxy Diner in East New York, Brooklyn, misstated the role that the police say Mark Blount, 27, played. He is charged with attempted robbery, assault and possession of a weapon, they said, but he is not believed to have acted as the getaway
title: Corrections

body: Looking for an upset in Tuesday's New York primary, Senator John Edwards rallied for votes in Brooklyn and in Albany yesterday, while Senator John Kerry sought to shore up support among upstate residents. But a contentious morning debate in New York City, filled with frequent interruptions and pointed exchanges, remained on the minds of the
title: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE CANDIDATES; Edwards and Kerry Make Last-Minute New York Push

body: A 14-year-old boy has been arrested in the Jan. 17 shootings at the Galaxy Diner in Brooklyn. He was identified by the police yesterday as one of two gunmen who wounded nine patrons and employees during a robbery early that morning. The police did not release the boy's name because he is a juvenile. They said he was arrested early Friday morning at
title: 14-Year-Old Arrested in Diner Shootings

author: Thomas Boyle, a professor of English at Brooklyn College, is the author of several crime novels set in Brooklyn.
body: OUT here in Brooklyn, we hear that New Jersey's Nets are coming. This could be great news, but at the same time it brings back the bitter memory of the nasty departure of our baseball Dodgers in 1957. And just over a week ago, Gage & Tollner, our oldest restaurant and most charming culinary relic of the dear departed 19th century (sorry about that,
title: CITY LORE; Put Down That Violin. Now.

body: The signs of Brooklyn's building boom are scattered across the borough, and they are not hard to read. ''Brand New Two-Family Homes -- Locations Include East New York, Bedford-Stuyvesant,'' blares one sign on Pitkin Avenue. ''Now Offering for Sale Luxury Two-Family Waterview Homes, Granite Kitchen,'' says another, along the quiet East Mill Basin
title: In a Brooklyn Boom, A Patchwork of Housing Fills In the Bare Spots

body: A suspect in a shooting spree that wounded nine people at a Brooklyn diner last month was found dead, apparently a suicide, in an Albany apartment Wednesday afternoon after being surrounded by the police, the authorities said yesterday. After the suspect, Ramel Simmons, 23, had been tracked to the apartment, New York City and Albany police officers
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Suspect In Shootings Found Dead

body: The New York City police sergeant who died on Saturday afternoon after chasing a man selling fake brand-name watches was a healthy man who traveled the world, but his brother said yesterday that the sergeant's travels could have contributed to his death. The sergeant, Keith Ferguson, 38, of Brooklyn, had returned a day earlier from a trip to
title: Brother Wonders if Travel Contributed to Officer's Death

body: A 38-year-old New York police sergeant sprinting after a fake watch dealer in SoHo collapsed on a sidewalk yesterday afternoon and died, the police said. The sergeant, Keith Ferguson of Brooklyn, an avid swimmer and diver and a 17-year veteran of the force, was a member of one of the elite Hercules Unit counterterrorism teams that patrol the city,
title: Police Sergeant Dies After Chasing Sidewalk Vendor in SoHo

body: For Joy Persaud, 49, of East New York, Brooklyn, the trouble starts when she hears a noise in her head. In those moments, no matter where she is, she sits on the floor, arms crossed, and waits for a seizure. Ms. Persaud has epilepsy, and three to five times a week the seizures come. Though this has been her life for five years, she remains fearless
title: The Neediest Cases; Recounting the Blessings of Life as Well as Its Battles

body: Spray from fire hoses freezes on the uniform, turning firefighters into stiff-armed ice figures. Spray hits the face and causes frostbite, or runs beneath the collar and breeds hypothermia. Hydrants freeze. Water freezes in hoses. Hoses freeze to the ground. Staircases turn into frozen waterfalls, and firefighters wearing 60 pounds of equipment
title: At End of Hose, A Hellish Blend Of Fire and Ice

body: A 22-year-old man was killed and three other men were injured in an outburst of violence that erupted on a street in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said. The man who died, Blake Harper, whose address was not determined last night, was shot once in the chest at 4:10 a.m. in front of 70 Pennsylvania Avenue in East New York, investigators said.
title: One Dead and 3 Hurt in Brooklyn Violence

body: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday in connection with an early-morning shooting and burglary in a diner last weekend that left nine people wounded, the police said. The man, Mark Blount, was taken into custody at 5:30 a.m., a police spokesman said. Mr. Blount, 27, lives on Miller Avenue in East New York, not far from the Galaxy Diner, where two
title: Man Held in Robbery and Shooting at Diner

body: On Jan. 8, Vanya Keenan turned 28. That day, while having surgery to replace a synthetic tube in her arm so that she could receive dialysis, she had a pulmonary embolism, when a floating blood clot in her veins blocked an artery to her lungs. ''On the table, I had shortness of breath; I couldn't breathe,'' she said as she sat in her bedroom in East
title: Getting Serious About a Kidney Transplant

body: With more than 100 supporters filling the steps of City Hall and chanting ''Charles in charge,'' Charles Barron, the Democratic city councilman from Brooklyn and a former Black Panther, announced his plan to run for mayor in 2005. Later, he received a major endorsement, that of the Rev. Al Sharpton, during a Martin Luther King's Birthday
title: Brooklyn Councilman to Run for Mayor in '05

body: The police released security camera images yesterday of the two men who shot and wounded several people during a robbery at a Brooklyn diner Saturday morning. Both men are shown wearing heavy winter coats. In one image, one of the men, who is wearing a knit hat, is shown pointing what looks to be a semiautomatic handgun. The police asked that
title: Police Release Images of Robbery at Diner

body: INTERNATIONAL 3-13 Helicopter Downings Show Greater Iraq Rebel Skills A classified Army study of the downings of military helicopters in Iraq found that guerrillas have used increasingly sophisticated tactics and weapons to attack American aircraft. 1 A large bomb exploded at the main gate of the American occupation headquarters in Baghdad on
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: Two men opened fire during a robbery at a Brooklyn diner early yesterday, wounding seven diners and a busboy and pistol-whipping a teenager before fleeing with cash and jewelry, the police said. Detectives said they had counted more than 20 shell casings inside and outside the Galaxy Diner at 805 Pennsylvania Avenue in East New York, from at least
title: Nine Injured, Most Slightly, as Armed Robbers Open Fire at a Brooklyn Diner

author: E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com
body: MICHAEL WATT doesn't like to admit that he is ''Ask Mr. Long Island,'' the know-it-all answer man on the www.longisland.com Web site. But as director of the site, Mr. Watt, 44, is the one who helps surfers find information they need. . While he calls being Mr. Long Island ''my secret life,'' Mr. Watt recently decided to come out of the trivia
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; The Answer Man at 'Ask Mr. Long Island'

body: The four-story walk-up is a form of housing not often produced in New York City any longer. But two new side-by-side walk-ups in Park Slope, Brooklyn, may lead the way to resurrecting it for rental housing designed for moderate-income tenants throughout the city. The developer is CPC Resources, the development arm of the Community Preservation
title: Residential Real Estate; Park Slope Walk-Up Revival May Signal New Rental Era

body: The Police Department is expanding a year-old anticrime initiative that narrowly focuses officers on neighborhoods, subway stations and housing projects with nagging crime problems, the mayor and the police commissioner announced yesterday. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly have often credited the initiative,
title: Police Widen Plan to Flood Crime Areas

body: In June 1998, Stacy Jenkinson of Brooklyn learned that she suffered from lupus nephritis, an inflammation of the kidney caused by an immune-system disease that can also harm the skin, joints and brain. This, after so many doctor visits, so many failed attempts to find out what was wreaking havoc with her body. ''I was really, really sick,'' she
title: The Neediest Cases; After Battling Illnesses, A Mother Gets Some Relief

body: Every day, Terry Diaz faces the same choice: Should she suffer through the severe pain in her left knee? Or should she take medication and stay in bed? Most days, the choice is made for her. After all, her children have to get to day care and she has to go to her job training program. So she skips the pill. She endures the pain, because her family
title: The Neediest Cases; Mother Takes Life's Demands One Painful Step at a Time

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Cold-Water Flat Days Q. I'm fascinated by the old Public Baths building on Huron Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. What is its history and what is the current state of its interior? A. When the Huron Street Public Bath opened at 139 Huron in 1904, it answered what was seen as a genuine public health need. Two years earlier, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle
title: F.Y.I.
